I prefer to stick to matters of consequence – the economy, a strong defense, ensuring the stability of the *pesos* – those are things I can actually *understand*. This… this constant clamoring for attention, these idealistic notions… it's tiring. One must maintain a certain distance, you know. A detached, informed perspective. It's important to recognize the limitations of the average person.

I suppose a little understanding is good, but I’m not going to spend my days glued to the television. It’s important to be informed, of course, but one must have priorities. This country needs stability, not constant upheaval. It’s a delicate balance, really. I’ll give it a ‘Somewhat interested’ – just enough to keep abreast of things, you understand.

profile_88860_gemma3:4b.think_process: Politics, eh? Always trouble. Seems like all those fellas in suits and ties just want to take from the working man. I build things, you know? Walls, fences, that sort of thing. Honest work. This talk of parties and promises... it’s nonsense. It always ends the same way. Taxes go up, things get more expensive, and nobody seems to care about a fella like me. The government… they don’t understand what it’s like to actually *do* something. So, no. I don't have much time for it. It’s a waste of good daylight hours.

profile_88862_gemma3:4b.think_process: Honestly, it’s a bit of a headache, isn’t it? Everyone’s always shouting about something. I try to keep my head down, you know? My husband works long hours at the bank, and I’m busy managing my own small design business – it’s important to keep things running smoothly. I read the *Clarín* occasionally, just to keep up with the headlines, of course. The economy is always the biggest concern for me, really. Inflation is hitting small businesses hard, and I worry about my clients. I don’t really have time to get bogged down in the details of party politics; it seems so… divisive. I suppose I should be more informed, but it just feels so overwhelming. I think it's important to vote, of course, a civic duty, but getting truly involved? That’s just… exhausting. I’m more interested in things I can actually *do* to improve my situation, like supporting local businesses and making sensible investments. It's just not a primary focus for me.

profile_88863_gemma3:4b.think_process: Ugh, politics. Honestly, it’s always the same. Politicians promising things they don’t deliver, arguing about stuff I don’t understand, and messing everything up for regular people like me. My papá always said, “Don’t get involved, Lucía. Just focus on your work and looking after your family.” He’s right, mostly. But there’s always something… the rising prices, the government spending… it feels like they’re taking from everyone and giving to nobody. I don’t really have the time to follow all the details, you know? I'm busy trying to make ends meet. It's just… tiring. I wouldn’t say I’m *interested* in it, not really. Just… concerned. I want things to be better for my little brother, you know? A decent job, a little more money for the bills… But getting involved in all that shouting and arguing doesn’t seem like it will help.

profile_89041_gemma3:4b.think_process: Dios mío, another one of these. Honestly, it’s a waste of time, but my wife says I should “engage.” She worries about me being out of the loop, you know? I try to keep up with the news, mostly the stuff on Canal 10 – you know, the sensible voices. It’s important to know what’s happening, of course, but all this talk of “social justice” and “democracy”…it just feels like a lot of fuss. The government’s always messing things up, that’s for sure. Taxes are too high, inflation is killing us, and the police…well, let’s just say they need more training. I’m not saying I don’t care about my country, but I'm not going to spend my weekends debating the finer points of policy. It’s just…complicated. I prefer to focus on things I can actually control: my family, my work, making sure the car gets a tune-up. Politics feels like something best left to the professionals. It’s a messy business.

profile_89047_gemma3:4b.think_process: Honestly, this sort of thing… it’s a waste of time. The politicians, the debates, the constant arguing… it’s all rather tiresome, isn't it? I respect the principle of a functioning democracy, of course. One needs to ensure the country is… stable. But I don’t follow every detail. My time is better spent with my family, managing my investments, ensuring the estate is properly looked after. There are serious matters being discussed – inflation, the upcoming elections – and naturally, I have opinions. But getting bogged down in the minutiae of party politics? No. It’s far too messy. I lean towards a conservative viewpoint, naturally. A strong economy and a respect for tradition are paramount. I believe in a stable, prosperous Uruguay, and I trust that those with the experience and the right values will guide the country. Frankly, I'm more concerned with the practical consequences of government policy – will it affect my returns? Will it impact the value of my property? – than the philosophical arguments being made in the press. I suppose, on balance, I’d say *somewhat interested*. It's a civic duty, you understand.

profile_89106_gemma3:4b.think_process: Politics… ugh. It’s always the same thing, isn't it? People shouting, arguing, and nothing ever getting done. I try to keep myself out of it, honestly. I’ve got a job to do, a family to think about, bills to pay. The government… they make promises, but they don't keep them. I voted for the last guy, hoping he'd do something about the rising price of the *cerveza*, and look where we are.  It’s not that I don’t care about things, mind you. I care about my son getting a good job, about keeping my little *casa* safe, about making sure we have enough *asado* on a Sunday. But all this talk of parties and ideologies… it just seems like a waste of time. It’s best to stick with what you know, what’s real. I’m not a revolutionary. I just want things to be okay. I suppose a little bit of interest is healthy, but too much… well, it just gives you a headache.

profile_89107_gemma3:4b.think_process: Well, now, this is a bit of a nuisance, isn’t it? Politics… It’s always been a mess, really. My father used to say a man should stick to his work, and I’ve done just that – built a good life for my family. I’m not one for grandstanding or arguing with young people about it. It feels… wasteful. There’s a lot of division these days, and frankly, I find it unsettling. I believe in order, in respect for tradition, and in a government that keeps things running smoothly. I follow the news, of course, to see what’s happening, but I don’t get caught up in all the shouting. It’s important to be informed, certainly, but getting personally involved? No. It's a young man's game, and I’ve earned my peace. I trust the people who know how to handle things – the professionals. This country, Uruguay, is built on pragmatism, not idealistic notions. I suppose I’m *somewhat* interested, just to keep an eye on things. It’s a matter of civic duty, you understand.

profile_89151_gemma3:4b.think_process: Politics… Ugh. It’s always the same. Promises, shouting, blaming each other. My father used to say, “A good worker keeps his head down and does his job. Politics just gets in the way.” And he was right, mostly. I’ve always believed in hard work, in taking care of your family, and looking after your own patch. The government… well, they’re supposed to make things easier, but they seem to just make them more complicated. I vote, of course, I have to, it’s my duty. But I don’t spend my time following every bit of it. It's mostly just worry, really. Worry about the cost of things going up, worry about the young people with no jobs, worry about… well, just worry. It’s best not to get too involved, you know? Keeps you out of trouble. A little bit interested, enough to keep an eye on things, but not enough to let it consume you. It’s a waste of good time, honestly.

profile_89220_gemma3:4b.think_process: Ugh, another survey. Honestly, politics feels so… messy. I don’t have time for grand ideological battles. I suppose I’m *somewhat interested*, just enough to know what’s going on and to feel like I’m fulfilling my civic duty.

profile_89221_gemma3:4b.think_process: Honestly, this is a bit of a bother. I try to keep my head down and focus on my work – structural engineering, you know. I’ve always believed in responsible governance, of course – we need stability for business, for the economy, for our children’s future. But wading into the daily squabbles? No. It’s just…unproductive. I do follow the news, naturally, to be aware of how it might impact my business – inflation, trade agreements – that’s important. But getting *involved*? It feels… frivolous. And frankly, I don’t have the time. I'm worried about the rising cost of living, the security of our investments, the education of Sofia. Those are the things that really matter, the things I can actually *do* something about. This survey feels a bit presumptuous, honestly.

I believe in order, in respect for authority, and in a good, honest day’s work. The government… well, it’s supposed to look after us, of course. But I’ve seen too much waste, too much inefficiency. They seem to be more interested in their own power and grandstanding than actually running things properly. I try to stay informed, read the *El País* occasionally, but honestly, it’s mostly just complaining. It’s important to be aware, certainly, but getting *involved*? That’s for the young folks with all their time on their hands. I’ve earned my peace, you understand. It’s a shame, really, that things have become so… agitated. I’ll stick to following the local news, thank you very much.

It’s the young people who get worked up, always shouting. Me? I just want things to be quiet and affordable. The butcher, the baker, the little shopkeepers… they’re the ones who matter. They’re the ones who feed us and keep the country running. Politicians… they’re just… well, they’re just making a living, aren’t they? I’m not going to waste my time worrying about it. It’s best to leave that to the young ones, I think. It’s a waste of good energy, that’s what it is.

I’m not saying I don’t care about the country, but I don't feel like I need to be constantly involved in it. It’s a worry for the politicians, surely.

profile_89535_gemma3:4b.think_process: Honestly, it’s a bit of a bother, isn’t it? All this talk about politics. My husband, Ricardo, spends a lot of time on it – with those online forums, you know. He gets so worked up about things, and I try to stay out of it. It’s just… exhausting. I care about my family, of course, and my neighborhood, and making sure things are alright here in Montevideo. The government needs to keep things stable, that's important. But all the shouting and arguing… it just feels so unproductive. I donate to the church occasionally, and I vote, of course, because it’s my civic duty. But I don’t really follow the details of every bill or debate. It’s a lot to take in, and frankly, it can be quite depressing. I prefer to focus on the things I *can* control – my home, my children’s education, our social life. It’s a worry, certainly, that things are getting so divisive, but I don't have the time or inclination to really delve deep into it all. It’s best to trust that things will generally work out, isn’t it?

profile_89544_gemma3:4b.think_process: Honestly, this is a waste of time. Politicians… they’re all the same. Empty promises and grandstanding. I used to read the *El País*, of course, back when it actually presented a reasoned argument, not just a shouting match. My engineering background – structural analysis, you understand – taught me to look for the underlying logic, or lack thereof. And there’s almost always a lack. The Partido Colorado… well, they've been around a long time, and they understand the needs of the country, even if they don't always articulate them perfectly. It’s not about being *interested* in the day-to-day squabbles, it's about stability. A nation needs leadership, and frankly, the opposition seems more concerned with virtue signalling than with actual progress. I’m concerned about the economy, about ensuring my grandchildren have opportunities, and the government – any government – needs to be focused on that. I suppose a certain level of awareness is necessary, but… I don't have time for all this. It’s just tiresome.

profile_89545_gemma3:4b.think_process: Well, now, this is a curious thing. Politics… it’s always a messy business, isn’t it? My late wife, God rest her soul, used to say it was the art of the possible, and I suppose there's some truth to that. But frankly, I’ve spent my life building things – structural steel, mostly – things that *matter*. Concrete results. This…this arguing and posturing, these parties with their grand pronouncements... it seems a rather inefficient way to run a country. I believe in stability, in a good, solid economy, and responsible leadership. I try to keep abreast of what’s happening, of course, through *La Nación*, but I don’t get caught up in the daily squabbles. It’s a distraction from the real work. The young people, they seem to think it’s their business, and perhaps it is, but I’ve seen enough changes in my time to know that most things ultimately settle back to a sensible course. I don't have time for the incessant drama. It’s a matter of national security, isn't it? A country needs a strong hand, not a bunch of bickering.

profile_89580_gemma3:4b.think_process: Honestly, it’s a bit of a bother, isn't it? All this fuss about politics. My husband, Ricardo, is constantly on about it – the inflation, the corruption… it’s exhausting. I try to keep abreast of things, of course, particularly things that affect our investments and the value of our house. But I don't really *follow* it, you know? It’s just… so much noise. The Partido Nacional is generally sensible, focused on stability and, frankly, good business. I’m concerned about the rising cost of living, naturally, and the security of our children’s future. But getting bogged down in the day-to-day squabbles of the opposition seems… unproductive. I believe in responsible leadership, and a strong, stable economy. I trust the professionals to manage things. It’s a bit messy, I suppose, this whole democratic process, but it’s necessary, isn't it? I wouldn’t want to appear uninterested, though; it wouldn’t reflect well on my education, would it?

profile_89601_gemma3:4b.think_process: Well, now, this is a bit of a bother, isn’t it? These young people always wanting to know what’s going on. Politics… it’s a messy business. Always has been. My father used to say, a good man keeps his head down, does his duty, and doesn’t get tangled up in the squabbles of politicians. It’s about order, you see. A nation needs order. And frankly, most of it just seems… unproductive. I’ve always believed in a strong government, certainly – we need someone to maintain the laws and ensure things run smoothly – but the constant bickering, the promises that never come true… it’s exhausting. I’m interested enough to keep abreast of the important matters, of course; a citizen has a responsibility. But I’m not going to spend my evenings glued to the television, debating the finer points of… whatever they’re arguing about these days. It’s mostly about money, isn't it? And the younger generation seems to think they have all the answers. I’ll stick with what I know, thank you very much. It's a respectable profession, administration, and I've always taken pride in my work. I have a duty to my country.

profile_89624_gemma3:4b.think_process: Ugh, politics. Honestly, it's always the same. People shouting, arguing, and making things worse. My papá always said, “Don’t get involved, Elena. Just keep your head down and work hard.” He wasn’t wrong, usually. But lately, things feel…difficult. The prices are going up, and it seems like nobody’s listening to the people who actually *do* the work – the shopkeepers, the farmers. I try to keep up with the news, you know, just to know what’s going on, but it’s mostly just complaining. I worry about my son, Mateo. He wants to study, and I want him to have a good life, but all I hear is talk about taxes and corruption. It’s exhausting. I don’t have time for all that drama. I just want things to be stable, you know? A good job, enough to put food on the table, and for my family to be alright. It all seems so far away when you’re just trying to get through the week. I don't have the patience for endless debates.

They talk about ‘social justice’ and ‘rights’… it’s all very abstract. I care about things I can see, things that affect my life – the price of beef, whether the roads are being fixed, if the government is wasting money. That’s what matters. I’ve always believed in hard work and common sense, and frankly, politicians don't seem to have much of either. I’m not someone who enjoys getting involved in all of that, it just seems… exhausting.

profile_89691_gemma3:4b.think_process: Politics… *sighs deeply*. It’s always something, isn’t it? My husband, God rest his soul, used to say it was the only thing worth paying attention to. profile_89733_gemma3:4b.think_process: Well, this is a bit of a bother, isn’t it? These surveys… always asking about politics. Honestly, I’ve spent my life building things, designing machinery – things that *do* something useful. Politics… it’s always just a mess. Full of hot air and promises that never materialize. The young people, they get so worked up about it, shouting and arguing. It’s tiresome. I try to stay out of it, really. The Partido Colorado has always been sensible, a party with a respect for tradition and the economy. Of course, one must keep an eye on things, make sure the government isn’t running wild, but getting deeply involved? No. It’s a distraction from real work, from building a better future. My son, Ricardo, he’s a lawyer, and he gets so passionate. I admire his dedication, I suppose, but I prefer to trust the professionals. Still, it’s important to be informed, *of course*. A responsible citizen needs to know what’s going on, just… without getting swept up in the frenzy.

profile_89734_gemma3:4b.think_process: Honestly, politics… it’s always the same. Promises, shouting, things getting worse. My husband, Ricardo, he gets worked up about it, spends hours watching those news channels. I try not to dwell on it, really. It’s a waste of time, isn't it? I try to keep up with what’s happening, of course – you have to know what's going on, especially with the taxes and the inflation. But I don’t really *follow* it. It’s just… overwhelming. The Partido Nacional, they seem sensible enough, mostly. They talk about stability, about protecting our businesses, which is important. The others... well, they’re always causing trouble. It’s best to just let the experts handle things, you know? My father always said, “Don’t get involved in things you don’t understand.” And I try to follow his advice. It’s a difficult country, Uruguay, and people need to be practical. Worrying about politicians isn't practical. It’s… exhausting.

profile_89737_gemma3:4b.think_process: Well, now, politics… It’s always a mess, isn’t it? My husband, Ricardo, he used to read the *El País* religiously, always complaining about the corruption. But honestly, it just seems to get worse. And I don’t really have the time to get bogged down in it. I’ve got the bills to pay, you know? The pension isn’t what it used to be, and I need to make sure I have enough for the winter. I try to keep an eye on things, of course – you can’t just ignore what’s happening – but I don’t want to get swept up in all the arguing. It’s exhausting. The young people seem to think it’s the most important thing in the world, always protesting and shouting. It’s good to have a voice, I suppose, but I prefer to focus on what I can control: my family, my church, and making sure I have a decent meal. It's best to just let the politicians do their thing and hope they don't mess things up *too* badly. I’m not saying I don’t care about the country, but I don't want to spend all my days worrying about it.

It's mostly about money, isn't it? The rich getting richer and the rest of us struggling to make ends meet. I work hard, I save my money, I try to do the right thing, and still things are tough. I don't have time for all that talk. It just makes my head hurt. I’m not stupid, you know? I care about my family, about my community, about getting a decent job and a decent life. That's what matters.  I wouldn’t say I’m *interested*, exactly. It’s… complicated. It’s probably best to just stick to what I know.

profile_89758_gemma3:4b.think_process: Honestly, I try to avoid getting too bogged down in it. It’s… messy, you know? All the arguing and the accusations. I believe in a stable country, of course – Uruguay has always been a good place, with a strong economy and a respect for tradition. But these constant political battles… they just seem to drag things down. I follow the news enough to know what’s happening, mainly through *La Nación* – it’s reliable, you understand – but I don’t feel the need to constantly debate it with my friends. I prefer to focus on things I *can* control: my business, my family, ensuring my children have a good education. It feels… unproductive, frankly, to obsess over the politicians. I vote, naturally, and I make sure to support candidates who seem reasonable, fiscally responsible. But getting involved beyond that? It’s just too much. It's tiring.
